slides.title: Ancient India
slides.content:
**Indus Valley Civilization:**
- One of the oldest civilizations (3300-1300 BCE)
- Major cities: Harappa, Mohenjo-Daro
- Known for: Planned cities, drainage system, Great Bath
- People knew: Agriculture, pottery, trade

**Vedic Period:**
- Four Vedas: Rigveda, Samaveda, Yajurveda, Atharvaveda
- Rigveda is the oldest
- Society divided into four varnas

**Mauryan Empire:**
- Founded by: Chandragupta Maurya
- Greatest ruler: Ashoka (269-232 BCE)
- Ashoka: Spread Buddhism, built stupas
- Capital: Pataliputra (modern Patna)

**Gupta Empire:**
- Called 'Golden Age of India'
- Rulers: Chandragupta I, Samudragupta, Chandragupta II
- Achievements: Science, mathematics, art, literature
- Aryabhata: Great mathematician and astronomer

slides.title: Medieval India
slides.content:
**Delhi Sultanate (1206-1526):**
- First Muslim kingdom in Delhi
- Five dynasties ruled
- Famous rulers:
  - Qutub-ud-din Aibak: Built Qutub Minar
  - Iltutmish: Introduced silver tanka
  - Alauddin Khilji: Market reforms
  - Muhammad bin Tughlaq: Shifted capital to Daulatabad

**Mughal Empire (1526-1857):**

**Babur (1526-1530):**
- Founder of Mughal Empire
- Won Battle of Panipat (1526)

**Akbar (1556-1605):**
- Greatest Mughal emperor
- Policy of religious tolerance (Din-i-Ilahi)
- Built Fatehpur Sikri
- Navratnas (Nine Gems) in his court

**Shah Jahan (1628-1658):**
- Built Taj Mahal (for wife Mumtaz Mahal)
- Built Red Fort, Jama Masjid

**Aurangzeb (1658-1707):**
- Last great Mughal emperor
- Expanded empire to largest extent
- Strict religious policies

slides.title: Freedom Struggle - Part 1
slides.content:
**British Rule in India:**

**Battle of Plassey (1757):**
- Robert Clive defeated Siraj-ud-Daulah
- Marked beginning of British rule

**Revolt of 1857:**
- First War of Independence
- Started in Meerut on May 10, 1857
- Leaders:
  - Mangal Pandey: Started revolt
  - Rani Lakshmibai: Queen of Jhansi
  - Bahadur Shah Zafar: Last Mughal emperor
  - Nana Sahib: Leader from Kanpur
  - Tantia Tope: Great military leader

**Indian National Congress:**
- Founded in 1885
- First President: W.C. Bonnerjee
- Early leaders: Dadabhai Naoroji, Gopal Krishna Gokhale

**Partition of Bengal (1905):**
- By Lord Curzon
- Divided Bengal into two parts
- Led to Swadeshi Movement
- Annulled in 1911

slides.title: Freedom Struggle - Part 2
slides.content:
**Mahatma Gandhi:**
- Known as 'Father of the Nation'
- Born: October 2, 1869
- Philosophy: Truth and Non-violence (Satyagraha)

**Major Movements:**

**1. Non-Cooperation Movement (1920-22):**
- Against Rowlatt Act and Jallianwala Bagh massacre
- Boycott of British goods, schools, courts

**2. Civil Disobedience Movement (1930):**
- Started with Dandi March (Salt Satyagraha)
- Gandhi marched 240 miles to make salt

**3. Quit India Movement (1942):**
- Slogan: 'Do or Die'
- Launched on August 8, 1942
- Demanded immediate independence

**Other Freedom Fighters:**
- Bhagat Singh: Hung at age 23
- Subhash Chandra Bose: Founded Indian National Army (INA)
- Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel: Iron Man of India
- Jawaharlal Nehru: First Prime Minister
- Dr. B.R. Ambedkar: Father of Indian Constitution

slides.title: Independence and After
slides.content:
**Independence (August 15, 1947):**
- India got independence from British rule
- First Prime Minister: Jawaharlal Nehru
- First President: Dr. Rajendra Prasad
- India divided into India and Pakistan

**Constitution of India:**
- Adopted on: November 26, 1949
- Came into force: January 26, 1950 (Republic Day)
- Chairman of Drafting Committee: Dr. B.R. Ambedkar
- Longest written constitution in the world

**Important Dates:**
- January 26: Republic Day
- August 15: Independence Day
- October 2: Gandhi Jayanti
- November 26: Constitution Day

**Prime Ministers of India:**
1. Jawaharlal Nehru (1947-64)
2. Lal Bahadur Shastri (1964-66) - 'Jai Jawan Jai Kisan'
3. Indira Gandhi (1966-77, 1980-84) - First woman PM
4. Rajiv Gandhi (1984-89) - Youngest PM
5. Atal Bihari Vajpayee (1998-2004)
6. Dr. Manmohan Singh (2004-14)
7. Narendra Modi (2014-present)

**Important Events:**
- 1971: Bangladesh Liberation
- 1974: First nuclear test (Pokhran)
- 1991: Economic Reforms
- 1998: Second nuclear test (Pokhran-II)
